utterances.transcript_with_note: [Scene: Monica and Rachel's apartment. Monica, Rachel, Ross, and Phoebe are there. Phoebe is looking out the window.]

utterances.transcript: Ooh, ooh, ooh, ooh, ooh. Ugly Naked Guy is decorating his tree. Oh my God, you should see the size of his Christmas Balls.
utterances.transcript_with_note: Ooh, ooh, ooh, ooh, ooh. Ugly Naked Guy is decorating his tree. Oh my God, you should see the size of his Christmas Balls. [Chandler and Joey enter.]

utterances.transcript: Hey.
Hey.
Hey.
Hey, how much did you guys tip the super this year?
Yeah, we were gonna give fifty, but if you guys gave more, we don't wanna look bad.
Oh, actually this year we just made him homemade cookies.
And twenty-five it is.
You gave him cookies?
Money is so impersonal. Cookies says someone really cares. . . Alright, we're broke, but cookies do say that.
I can see that. A plate of brownies once told me a limerick.
Phoebs, let me ask you something, were, were these, uh, funny brownies?
Not especially. But you know what, I think they had pot in them.
So you guys, who else did you tip with cookies?
Uhh, the mailman, the super.
utterances.transcript_with_note: Uhh, the mailman, the super. [There's a bang at the door.]

utterances.transcript: Oh, and the newspaper delivery guy.
utterances.transcript_with_note: Oh, and the newspaper delivery guy. [Joey opens the door and picks up the remnants of the newspaper.]

utterances.transcript: Oh my God.
What?
Uhhh, I don't think you're gonna like this.
utterances.transcript_with_note: Uhhh, I don't think you're gonna like this. [Joey shows them the torn-up newspaper.]

utterances.transcript: Ooh, goooosh, ooh, these are cookies smashed in the sports section.
Oh look, and he did my crossword puzzle.
Yeah, but not very well, unless 14-across, 'Gershwin musical' actually is bitemebitemebitemebiteme.

utterances.transcript_with_note: [Scene: Central Perk. Monica, Chandler, and Joey are seated at couches. Rachel is working behind the counter.]

utterances.transcript: I can't believe it's Christmas already. Ya know, I mean, one day your eatin' turkey, the next thing ya know, your lords are a-leapin' and you geese are a-layin'.
Which is why geese are so relaxed this time of year.
utterances.transcript_with_note: Which is why geese are so relaxed this time of year. [Ross enters with several bags from shopping.]

utterances.transcript: Hey guys.
Hey.
utterances.transcript_with_note: Hey. [Ross approaches Rachel at counter.]

utterances.transcript: Hey Rach. I, uh, got you a little present. . . I'll open it. It's a Slinky! Remember, huh. Walks down stairs, alone or in pairs, everyone knows it's. . . just a big spring. Alright, you still mad at me becuase of the whole. . .
utterances.transcript_with_note: Hey Rach. I, uh, got you a little present. [Rachel is not impressed]. . I'll open it. It's a Slinky! Remember, huh. [sings] Walks down stairs, alone or in pairs, everyone knows it's. . . just a big spring. Alright, you still mad at me becuase of the whole. . .

utterances.transcript: Horrible and degrading list of reasons not to be with me?
How 'bout from now on we just call it the 'unfortunate incident'? Hey Gunther, you got stairs in your place?
utterances.transcript_with_note: How 'bout from now on we just call it the 'unfortunate incident'? [Rachel walks off] Hey Gunther, you got stairs in your place?

utterances.transcript: Yeah.
Here, go nuts.
utterances.transcript_with_note: Here, go nuts. [gives him the Slinky and goes and sits with others at the couches]

utterances.transcript: Hey guys.
Hey.
What's in the bag?
Um, just some presents.
C'mon show us what you bought. . . You know you want to.
OK. OK, this is a picture frame from Ben to my parents, huh.
utterances.transcript_with_note: [childishly] OK. OK, this is a picture frame from Ben to my parents, huh.

utterances.transcript: Cute.
I got some, uh, hers and hers towels for Susan and Carol. And, uh, I got this blouse for mom.
utterances.transcript_with_note: I got some, uh, hers and hers towels for Susan and Carol. And, uh, I got this blouse for mom. [Ross holds up the blouse. It is extremely tacky, with sewn-on medals hanging off of it.]

utterances.transcript: Ross, that is gorgeous!
Yeah?
Look at these authentic fake medals. I tell ya, mom's gonna be voted best dressed at the make-believe military academy.
utterances.transcript_with_note: Look at these authentic fake medals. I tell ya, mom's gonna be voted best dressed at the make-believe military academy. [Phoebe enters.]

utterances.transcript: Hey.
Hey. Hi Phoebe.
Happy Christmas Eve Eve. Oh my God, where did you get this?
utterances.transcript_with_note: Happy Christmas Eve Eve. [sees Ross's picture frame] Oh my God, where did you get this?

utterances.transcript: Uh, Macy's, third floor, home furnishings.
This is my father, this is a picture of my dad.
Nah, Phoebs, that's the guy that comes in the frame.
No it isn't, this is my dad, alright, I'll show you.
Phoebe, I thought your dad was in prison.
No, that's my stepdad. My real dad's the one that ran out on us before I was born.
How have you never been on Oprah?
OK, look, see, this is him. My mother gave me this picture before she died, same guy.
utterances.transcript_with_note: [showing her pictures] OK, look, see, this is him. My mother gave me this picture before she died, same guy.

utterances.transcript: Honey, uh, this is a picture of the frame guy posing in front of a bright blue screen with a collie.
It's not a blue screen... it's just, maybe it was just really clear that day. OK, I have to talk to my grandmother.
utterances.transcript_with_note: It's not a blue screen... it's just, maybe it was just really clear that day. OK, I have to talk to my grandmother. [turns to leave]

utterances.transcript: Oh, wait a minute honey.
Phoebs.
utterances.transcript_with_note: Phoebs. [Phoebe leaves]

utterances.transcript: Wow.
So anyway, I'm trying to get my boss's ex-wife to sleep with me. . .
Joey!
Oh, but when Phoebe has a problem, everyone's all ears!

utterances.transcript_with_note: [Scene: Phoebe's grandmother's place. Phoebe's grandmother is sitting at the table, reading the obituaries, and crossing out names in the phonebook.]

utterances.transcript: Esther Livingston. Gone.
utterances.transcript_with_note: Esther Livingston. [scratches out name] Gone. [Phoebe enters.]

utterances.transcript: Hi, Phoe.
Hi Gram. Whatcha doin'?
Oh, just updating the phonebook.
Um, gram, um, can I see the pictures of my dad again?
Oh. Oh, sure, sure, uh, uh, how come?
utterances.transcript_with_note: [nervously] Oh. Oh, sure, sure, uh, uh, how come?

utterances.transcript: Just, you know, to see... um.
Oh, sure, yeah. This is the one of you father in a meadow, and, uh, helping a little boy fly a kite, and here he is at a graduation. . . another graduation. . . another graduation.
utterances.transcript_with_note: Oh, sure, yeah. [gets a box with the pictures] This is the one of you father in a meadow, and, uh, helping a little boy fly a kite, and here he is at a graduation. . . another graduation. . . another graduation.

utterances.transcript: OK, is this really my father?
Is it really your fa--I can't... well of course it is.
OK, I smell smoke. Maybe that's 'cause someone's pants are on fire.
Look, I. . .
Ya know, in all the years that we have been grandmother and granddaughter, you have never lied to me.
Alright, that is not your father, that's just a picture of a guy in a frame.
Oh God.

It was your mother's idea. Ya know, she didn't want you to know your real father because it hurt her so much when he left, and, I didn't want to go along with it, but, well then she died and, and it was harder to argue with her. Not impossible, but harder.
Alright, so, what, he's not a famous tree surgeon? And then, I guess, OK, he doesn't live in a hut in Burma where there's no phones?
Last I heard, he was a pharmacist somewhere upstate.
OK, that makes no sense. Why would the villagers worship a pharmacist?
Honey.
Oh.
utterances.transcript_with_note: [realizes] Oh.

utterances.transcript: Anyway, that's all I know. That, and this. This is the real him.
utterances.transcript_with_note: Anyway, that's all I know. That, and this. [pulls apart a frame and pulls a picture out] This is the real him.

utterances.transcript: Oh.

plots: Phoebe discovers that everything Phoebe thought Phoebe knew about Phoebe 's biological father ( including the father 's picture ) is a lie .
Phoebe is stunned to find a picture of Phoebe father in Ross ' photo frame , but Phoebe soon realizes it 's a guy - in - the - frame picture and has suspects on Phoebe real father .

When Phoebe asks for the truth , Phoebe 's grandmother admits to Phoebe that Phoebe 's grandmother does n't know anything about Phoebe 's dad - except for the fact that Phoebe 's dad a pharmacist upstate and Phoebe 's dad 's home address .
Phoebe becomes very upset after learning that Phoebe 's grandmother lied to Phoebe about Phoebe 's father .
Phoebe 's grandmother also hands Phoebe a real picture of Phoebe 's father .
Phoebe 's grandmother lied about pictures of a man in the photo album .
Phoebe and Phoebe 's Grandmother discuss her paternity and the true identity of Phoebe 's father .

utterances.transcript_with_note: [Scene: Monica and Rachel's apartment. Rachel, Chandler, and Joey are decorating the Christmas tree.]

utterances.transcript: Ya know I remember my father, all dressed up in the red suit, the big black boots, and the patent leather belt, sneakin around downstairs. He didn't want anybody to see him but he'd be drunk so he'd stumble, crash into something and wake everybody up.
Well, that doesn't sound like a very merry Christmas.
Who said anything about Christmas?
utterances.transcript_with_note: Who said anything about Christmas? [Monica and Ross enter.]

utterances.transcript: Hi.
Hey, anyone hear from Phoebe yet?
No, nothin'.
I hope she's OK.
Yeah, I know exactly what she's goin' through.
How do you know exactly what she's going through?
She told us.
So whaddya got there Monica?
Just some stuff for the party.
Yeah, what're you guys doin' here, aren't you supposed to be Christmas shopping?
You guys haven't gotten your presents yet? Tomorrow's Christmas Eve, what're ya gonna do?
Don't you have to be Claymation to say stuff like that?
Oh, by the way Mon, I don't think the mailman liked your cookies. Here are the ornaments your mom sent.
utterances.transcript_with_note: Oh, by the way Mon, I don't think the mailman liked your cookies. Here are the ornaments your mom sent. [hands her a smashed box]

utterances.transcript: Well, maybe the mailman liked the cookies, we just didn't give him enough.
Monica, pigeons learn faster that you.
utterances.transcript_with_note: Monica, pigeons learn faster that you. [Ross approaches Rachel, away from everyone else.]

utterances.transcript: Hey, Rach, you know what? I think, I think I know what'll make you feel better. How 'bout you make a list about me.
Wha... forget it Ross, no, I am not gonna stand here and make a list of. . .
C'mon Rachel.

OK, you're whiney, you are, you're obsessive, you are insecure, you're, you're gutless, you know, you don't ever, you don't just sort of seize the day, you know. You like me for what, a year, you didn't do anything about it. And, uh, oh, you wear too much of that gel in your hair.
See there, you uhh, alright, ya, you did what I said.
Yeah, and you know what? You're right, I do feel better, thank you Ross.
utterances.transcript_with_note: Yeah, and you know what? You're right, I do feel better, thank you Ross. [she walks off and Ross puts his hand to his hair]

plots: Monica and Rachel , low on funds , make cookies to give instead of cash as holiday tips to the paperboy , the mailman , the superintendent , etc.
Ross tells Rachel to make a list about him , so Rachel does ; Ross obsesses about Rachel 's complaints .
Chandler and Rachel talk about a Christmas in the past .
Chandler and Joey have to do their Christmas shopping late on Christmas eve .
Rachel tells Ross how Rachel really feels about Ross , making Rachel feel better .
At Monica 's , Ross asks Rachel to make a list of cons Ross has to try and make Rachel feel better , and then obsesses about them .
Monica wonders how Joey and Chandler are going to get Christmas Shopping done as tomorrow 's Christmas eve

utterances.transcript_with_note: [Scene: Monica and Rachel's apartment. Monica is preparing for the party with Ross questioning her.]

utterances.transcript: C'mon, just tell me, please, please.
For the sixteenth time, no... I do not think you're obsessive.
utterances.transcript_with_note: For the sixteenth time, no... I do not think you're obsessive. [Rachel enters from her room]

utterances.transcript: Oh, gosh, it's hot in here.
Rach, get the heat. Ross, could you turn the heat down please?
utterances.transcript_with_note: Rach, get the heat. [Rachel holds up her hand with wet fingernail polish] Ross, could you turn the heat down please?

utterances.transcript: Sure. By the way, there's a difference between being obsessive and. . .
Ross, the heat!
Fine, OK! Heat, heat, heat, and I'm the obsessive one. OK, this way is on, so this is. . . off.
utterances.transcript_with_note: Fine, OK! Heat, heat, heat, and I'm the obsessive one. [goes to the radiator and starts turning the knob] OK, this way is on, so this is. . . [breaks off the knob] off.

utterances.transcript: Did you just break the radiator?
No, no, I was turnin' the knob and, and. . . here it is.
Well put it back.
It uhh, it won't go back.
I'll call the super.
Here, let me try.
Oh, oh that's right, I forgot about your ability to fuse metal.
Hey, it's Funny's cousin, Not Funny.

Hi, Mr. Treeger. Hi, it's Rachel Green from upstairs. Yes, somebody, uh, broke our knob on the radiator and it's really hot in here. Yes, it's, it's hot enough to bake cookies. Well, do you think we could have a new one by 6? Wha t, no, no, Tuesday, we can't wait until Tuesday, we're having a party tonight.
utterances.transcript_with_note: [on phone] Hi, Mr. Treeger. Hi, it's Rachel Green from upstairs. Yes, somebody, uh, broke our knob on the radiator and it's really hot in here. Yes, it's, it's hot enough to bake cookies. Well, do you think we could have a new one by 6? Wha t, no, no, Tuesday, we can't wait until Tuesday, we're having a party tonight.

utterances.transcript: OK, tip the man.
No, if he doesn't like our cookies, too bad, I am not gonna be blackmailed. Look if worse comes to worse, it gets a little warm, we'll call it a theme party.
Hey, here's a theme: Come on in, live like bacon.

utterances.transcript: Hi, welcome to our tropical Christmas party. You can put your coats and sweaters and pants and shirts in the bedroom.

utterances.transcript: It's hard to tell because I'm sweating, but I use exactly what the gel bottle says, an amount about the size of a pea. How, how can that be too much?

utterances.transcript_with_note: [Scene: Monica and Rachel's apartment. Ross, Monica, and Rachel are sitting around after the party. Chandler, Joey, and Phoebe enter.]

utterances.transcript: Ho, ho, ho, holy crap is it hot in here!

Hey, guys, it's after midnight, merry Christmas everyone.
utterances.transcript_with_note: Hey, guys, it's after midnight, merry Christmas everyone. [Ross and Phoebe hug, Monica and Rachel hug, Chandler is left standing]

utterances.transcript: Hey, Monica, the knob was broken so I just turned it off from underneath, I hope that's alright.

plots: Despite the heat , Rachel and Monica have a big Christmas party .

The guys and Phoebe make their way to Monica 's apartment where the heat hits them - to everyone 's surprise , Joey manages to turn off the heat by telling Monica that since the knob was broken , he turned the heat off from underneath .

utterances.transcript_with_note: They're ribbed for your pleasure. [Ross and Monica trade their gifts.]

plots: After , the group begins gift - giving , and Chandler and Joey start giving out theirs .

Theirs are plainly the most bizarre Christmas gifts - Rachel gets wiper blades and a bottle of car smell ; Phoebe gets toilet seat covers ; Ross obtains a cola drink and a lemon - lime ; whilst Monica receives a packet of ribbed condoms .
